docs.lead_paragraph: Rachel Jessica Baer, a daughter of Susan and Edward Baer of Rockville Centre, N.Y., is to be married today to David Andrew Blechman, the son of Elaine and Michael Blechman of Chappaqua, N.Y. Rabbi Alan D. Fuchs is officiating at the Tribeca Rooftop in New York. The bride, 29, is a marketing associate in the Women's Health Group of Pfizer, the pharmaceuticals company, in New York. She graduated from Rutgers and received an M.B.A. from Columbia. Her father, who is retired, was assistant general counsel for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: SIGNING bonuses. Flex time. Tuition benefits and scholarships. Are these enticements from Fortune 500 corporations for prospective new hires? No, these lures are for nurses.
docs.abstract: Article on efforts by hospitals and colleges in Westchester County, NY, to recruit and retain nurses and prospective nurses through signing bonuses, flex time, job guarantees after college and scholarships; photo (M)
docs.snippet: SIGNING bonuses. Flex time. Tuition benefits and scholarships.     Are these enticements from Fortune 500 corporations for prospective new hires?    No, these lures are for nurses.

docs.lead_paragraph: HOSPITAL leaders who oversaw construction of the 19-story building that the Nassau County Medical Center moved into in 1974 said it would be the pre-eminent medical facility on Long Island. Secure in their confidence, they built three extra floors and left them empty for future development. Twenty-eight years later, the three floors are still unfinished and the 631-bed hospital is fighting for its life.

headline.main: A Glimmer Amid the Gloom in East Meadow

docs.abstract: Article on struggles of Nassau County Medical Center, which started out as Meadowbrook Hospital and is now known as Nassau University Medical Center; hospital, which has lost money every year in its 67-year history, is seeking to attract middle-class patients; photos (M)
docs.snippet: HOSPITAL leaders who oversaw construction of the 19-story building that the Nassau County Medical Center moved into in 1974 said it would be the pre-eminent medical facility on Long Island. Secure in their confidence, they built three extra floors...

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR nearly four years, Herman Cole, 43, of Bridgeport has made a daily pilgrimage to his wife's bedside at Norwalk Hospital to attend to her personal needs, spend time with her and let her know that he will always love her. His wife, Sadie Kinder Cole, went to the hospital on July 15, 1998, as a healthy 36-year-old mother of three for what she and her husband expected to be a routine procedure. But something went wrong during her elective tubal ligation. ''It was the worst day of my life,'' Mr. Cole recalled. ''I felt like my world was torn apart, knowing the vibrant woman I expected to live my life with would never speak or make love with me again. I will never get over it.''

headline.main: The View From/Norwalk; After Surgery Goes Bad, Who Must Pay the Bill?

docs.abstract: Article on dispute between Norwalk Hospital in Connecticut and family of Sadie Kinder Cole, who became completely and permanently disabled while undergoing tubal ligation in July 1998; hospital has sued Cole's husband seeking $3 million for care provided since that time and contending that woman should be transferred to long-term care center; Herman Cole has filed malpractice suit against anesthesiologist Jay Angeluzzi, gynecologist Marjorie Szeto and hospital and wants hospital to pay for round-the-clock care at home; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: SEPT. 11 continues to have a major effect on the New Jersey office market, in exactly the opposite way real-estate experts' instincts initially indicated. ''There's a ton of sublet space out there now,'' said Ken Flynn Jr., a vice president of the commercial broker Trammell Crow, ''as there has been since 9/11, when just about anything that was empty was put on the market.''

headline.main: Commercial Property/New Jersey; A Flood of Office Space Is Offered for Subleasing

docs.abstract: Glut of sublet commercial space in New Jersey confounds experts who thought many businesses would relocate there after Sept 11; some space was grabbed up, but mostly for short-term leases as companies decide how to proceed; overall vacancy rate in northern and central New Jersey is 18 percent; photo (M)
docs.snippet: SEPT. 11 continues to have a major effect on the New Jersey office market, in exactly the opposite way real-estate experts' instincts initially indicated.    ''There's a ton of sublet space out there now,'' said Ken Flynn Jr., a vice president of the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Memorial Health University Medical Center has ambitious goals for itself, and executives here hope Deepak Chopra can help achieve them. In a bid to become a regional leader in health care by combining traditional and alternative medicine, the hospital has joined with Dr. Chopra, the best-selling author and holistic health guru, to create a center where patients and Savannah residents can come for yoga, meditation or a treatment called Shirodhara in which warm herbalized sesame oil is dripped languorously onto their foreheads. The embrace of mantras and massage is not limited to Memorial. In March of last year, St. Joseph's/Candler, Memorial's only rival in Savannah, opened a Center for Wellbeing, where people can take yoga classes and learn about aromatherapy. And in May, St. Joseph's will introduce a program affiliated with the Mind/Body Medical Institute, founded by Herbert Benson, the Harvard physician who has been at the forefront of advocating the health benefits of reducing stress.

headline.main: Alternative Medicine Is Finding Its Niche In Nation's Hospitals

docs.abstract: Hospitals in search of paying patients and competitive edge are increasingly offering some form of alternative medicine; 15.5 percent of all hospitals offered alternative therapies in 2000 and hospitals of all sizes are continuing to open alternative or complementary medicine centers serving patients and local residents; market for such services is estimated at around $27 billion; center Memorial Health University Medical Center, Savannah, Ga, runs with holistic health guru Dr Deepak Chopra cited; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Memorial Health University Medical Center has ambitious goals for itself, and executives here hope Deepak Chopra can help achieve them. In a bid to become a regional leader in health care by combining traditional and alternative medicine, the...

byline.original: By REED ABELSON with PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

docs.lead_paragraph: Workers at Lawrence Hospital have voted to join 1199/S.E.I.U., the giant health care union, giving it a victory at a hospital that it first tried to organize 37 years ago. Dennis Rivera, 1199's president, invested a lot of energy, money and prestige into the effort to organize the hospital's 270 nonprofessional workers, vowing to win after 1199 narrowly lost a unionization drive a year ago. The union spent $1.3 million on the campaign, or $9,000 for each worker who voted to join.

headline.main: After 37 Years, Union Wins At a Hospital in Bronxville

docs.abstract: Workers at Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, NY, vote to join Local 1199, Service Employees International Union; union first tried to organize hospital 37 years ago and vows to organize every hospital in Westchester County (M)
docs.snippet: Workers at Lawrence Hospital have voted to join 1199/S.E.I.U., the giant health care union, giving it a victory at a hospital that it first tried to organize 37 years ago.    Dennis Rivera, 1199's president, invested a lot of energy, money and...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the past, most hospitals and doctors steered clear of many alternative medical treatments. But in recent years, with some studies showing that as many as 43 percent of Americans have used some form of alternative medicine, medical experts are reconsidering. In March, the White House Commission on Complementary and Alternative Medicine Policy released a report on alternative therapies calling for increased research spending, more coverage by insurance companies and more Medicare coverage of these treatments.

headline.main: Verdict Is Still Out on Some Alternative Therapies

docs.abstract: Medical experts remain sharply divided on alternative medicine, with American Medical Association citing absence of evidence to confirm safety or efficacy of most such therapies; even White House commission that called for more research spending and insurance coverage was at odds over therapies (M)
docs.snippet: In the past, most hospitals and doctors steered clear of many alternative medical treatments. But in recent years, with some studies showing that as many as 43 percent of Americans have used some form of alternative medicine, medical experts are...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''V.A. Health Care Strained by Big Wave of Enrollees'' (front page, April 6): As a veteran in the Veterans Affairs Department health care system since 1999, I'd like to point out that the high cost of drugs is only one reason for enrolling. Health insurance is another. I'm self-employed, and one of the 43 million Americans without insurance because it's too expensive. Healthy men in their late 50's are high risks for insurers and, as you pointed out recently, for private physicians as well.
docs.abstract: Eric Breitbart letter on growing number of veterans enrolling in Veterans Affairs Dept health care system (April 6 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: Yale University has approved a new policy to reimburse students who have lost their federal financial aid because of a conviction for drug possession. Since no Yale student has lost eligibility for federal aid under the four-year-old drug-free provision of the Higher Education Act, the new policy is largely a public statement by Yale, acknowledged Thomas Conroy, a university spokesman.

headline.main: Yale's Policy Makes Stand On Drug Law

docs.abstract: Yale University approves policy to reimburse students who have lost financial aid because of conviction for drug possession; no Yale student has lost federal aid eligibility under drug-free provision of Higher Education Act, so new policy is largely public statement; Yale is fourth college to take position contrary to federal antidrug provision passed by Congress in 1998 (M)
